'Deoxyribose', or more precisely '2-deoxyribose', is a monosaccharide with
idealized formula H-(C=O)-(CH 2)-(CHOH) 3-H. Its name
indicates that it is a deoxy sugar, meaning that it is derived from the sugar
ribose by loss of an oxygen atom. Since the pentose sugars arabinose and ribose
only differ by the stereochemistry at C2', 2-deoxyribose and 2-deoxyarabinose
are equivalent, although the latter term is rarely used because ribose, not
arabinose, is the precursor to deoxyribose.
